title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Sir John Scott of Thirlestane, his maternal ancestor, was the only chief willing to follow James V. in his invasion of England, when the rest of the Scottish nobles, encamped at Fala, obstinately refused to take part in the expedition.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Thedeath of his two sons, and the disgrace of the defection at Fala, had made a deepimpression on his mind, and haunted him even in the visions of the night.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He assembled the array of his kingdom, and marched from Edinburgh as far asFala, on his way to the Border, when tidings arrived, 1st November, 1542, thatthe English general had withdrawn his forces within the English frontier.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Hawley seems to be sensible ofhis misconduct, for, when I was with him on Saturday morning, at Linlithgow, he looked most wretchedly, even worsethan Cope did a few hours after his scuffle, when I saw himat Fala.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The death of his two sons,and the disgrace of the defection at Fala, had madea deep impression on his mind, and haunted himeven in the visions of the night.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 2 How Hawley looked on this occasion, we learn bv a letterfrom General Wightman to President Forbes.—""GeneralHawley is in much the same situation as General Cope : hewas never seen in the field during tbe battle; and every thingwould have gone to wreck, in a worse manner than at Preston,if General Huske had not acted with judgment and courage,and appeared every where- Hawley seems to be sensible ofhis misconduct, for, when I was with him on Saturday morning, at Linlithgow, he looked most wretchedly, even worsethan Cope did a few hours after his scuffle, when 1 saw himat Fala- — Cuttoden Papers, p.
